title: Looking back at the European Public Domain Day 2026
content: On 15 January, we celebrated the Public Domain Day 2026 at the Royal Library of Belgium, bringing together advocates, academics and practitioners from a variety of backgrounds. Like every year the expiry of copyright protection has led to many “new” heritage works entering the Public Domain. title: Consultation submission: Digital Omnibus
content: Last week, we submitted our response to the European Commission’s consultation on the Digital Omnibus (PDF file). While the Commission already published its draft regulation in November 2025, the feedback period will remain open until 13 March 2026. We reiterate our belief that a more transparent and deliberate process, including extensive consultation with stakeholders before the release of the proposal, would have led to a stronger outcome. title: INI on copyright and generative AI: After the vote
content: Today, the JURI Committee adopted Axel Voss’s own-initiative report on copyright and generative AI . The Committee also endorsed all compromise amendments, some of which reflect concerns raised by COMMUNIA and other stakeholders. However, even with these changes, the report still contains ambiguities and problematic language that risk creating legal uncertainty, particularly for researchers and developers of public-interest AI systems. title: After CDSMD: Why Copyright TPMs Remain Harmful to the Knowledge Ecosystem
content: The review of the DSM Directive is just around the corner. To mark the occasion, we’ve invited several experts to reflect on the issues the Directive aimed to fix—but didn’t. Kristofer Erickson’s guest post reviews new research highlighting the the failure of Articles 6 and 7 to solve the constraints posed by technological protection measures. title: INI on copyright and generative AI: Final assessment and recommendation
content: MEP Axel Voss’s own-initiative report on copyright and generative AI will be put to a vote in the JURI Committee on 28 January. Although framed as a response to legitimate questions around AI and copyright, the proposal suffers from serious shortcomings, most notably its disregard for the existing legal framework. title: Submission to the open consultation on the ERA Act
content: Yesterday, we submitted our response ( PDF file ) to the public consultation questionnaire on the European Research Area (ERA) Act . title: Protect the Public Domain: Stop the 70-year term for non-creative photographs
content: Italy has adopted a legal amendment to extend the term of exclusive rights for simple photographs from 20 to 70 years, a drastic shift that may cause serious damage, unless corrective action is taken. title: Our thoughts on the current state of the INI on Copyright and generative AI
content: In July, MEP Axel Voss released his draft for an own initiative report on Copyright and generative AI in the JURI Committee. While the proposal was well-intentioned, in our initial reaction we were quick to criticize numerous aspects of the text, most notably its disregard for the existing legal framework, ambiguous proposals and lack of users’ rights safeguards. title: The Digital Omnibus and open data: Risks for open projects
content: The EU’s Digital Omnibus Proposal has sparked controversy, especially over the planned changes to the data protection regime. But the package goes beyond privacy rules. One amendment to the Open Data Directive in particular could have serious consequences, potentially undermining open projects such as the Wikimedia projects. title: Submission to the CSPLA questionnaire on AI-generated outputs
